document.masterDocTitle: A synopsis of the Neotropical genus Nephepeltia (Odonata: Libellulidae), including description of a new species, synonymies, and a key to males

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A synopsis of the Neotropical genus Nephepeltia (Odonata: Libellulidae), including description of a new species, synonymies, and a key to males

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Libellula phryne
Perty, 1833
: 116
, Pl. 25 , fig. 3 (description based on ♂ syntype from Provincia Piauhiensi, with color plate of body, deposited in ZSM ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Nephepeltia phryne
—
Kirby ( 1889 : 259, 310 ; description of genus)
;—
Calvert ( 1906 : 230 –231 , Pl. 9 , figs. 31–33 ; in key, records from Guatemala , Panama , and Brazil , illustrations of S 10 , genital fossa, ventral thoracic spine, and wings)
;—
Ris ( 1911 : 394–395 , fig. 242 ; in key, redescription, illustration of wings)
;—
Geijskes ( 1932 : 108 ; records from Trinidad and Tobago )
;—
Santos ( 1950 : 30–44 , figs. 1 –2, 5–6, 9–10, 19–26, 29–30, 33–34, 37– 39 ; redescription, illustrations of ♂ ventral thoracic tubercle, anterior lamina, genital fossa, S 10 , and vesica, and of ♀ pronotum and S 9–10 )
;—
Rácenis ( 1953 : 134–135 , records from Venezuela )
;—
Geijskes ( 1971 : 669 ; record from French Guiana )
;—
Burmeister ( 1983
: 270–272 , figs. 2 a,b; designation of lectotype , photographs and notes on lectotype and paralectotype and accompanying labels);—
De
Marmels ( 1990
: 11–12 , figs. 41–44 ; description of larva based on reared ♀);—
De
Marmels ( 1992
: 67 ; record from Venezuela );—
Boomsma & Dunkle ( 1996 : 27 ; record from Belize )
.

Nephepeltia phryne phryne—
Santos ( 1950 : 36–40 , figs. 1 –2, 5–6, 9–10, 19, 22, 21, 24, 29–30, 33–34, 37, 39, 43; description based on specimens from Amazonas, Mato Grosso, Minas Gerais, São Paulo, and Rondônia States in Brazil and Paramaribo in Surinam ; illustrations of ♂ ventral thoracic tubercle, anterior lamina, genital fossa, S 10 , and vesica, and of ♀ S 9–10 )
;—
Costa et al. ( 2000
: 16 , records from São Paulo State, Brazil ).

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Nephepeltia phryne tupiensis
Santos, 1950
: 34
–35, figs. 5 –6, 20, 23, 25–26, 38, 41 (description based on specimens from Espírito Santo, Pernambuco, Rio de Janeiro, and São Paulo States in Brazil , holotype from Espírito Santo State, Riberão do Engano, Vale do Itaúna,
ix 1944
, Travassos & Santos leg., deposited in MNRJ ; illustrations of ♂ ventral thoracic tubercle, anterior lamina, genital fossa, S 10 , and vesica spermalis, and of ♀ pronotum);
Costa et al. ( 2000
: 16
, records from São Paulo State, Brazil ). New synonymy.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 9. Male genital lobe, ventral view. o.b.: outer branch of hamule.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Justification of synonymy of
Nephepeltia phryne tupiensis
Santos, 1950
.
Santos described the subspecies
N. p. tupiensis
based on his observations indicating that specimens from the ‘Tupi’ province of the Brazilian subregion along the Atlantic coast of Brazil (
Santos, 1950 : map
) differed from other specimens of
N. phryne
by their ventral thoracic tubercle being longer, wider at base, and with an acute apex, larger size, hyaline wings, and some other minor differences in the shape of anterior lamina cleft and male caudal appendages. Examination of numerous additional specimens from this area in Brazil and elsewhere in the Neotropical region revealed that the shape and size of the ventral thoracic tubercle (
Fig. 8
) and other suggested characters are variable throughout the range of the species, and therefore can provide no evidence for the distinction of two subspecies, thus
N. phryne tupiensis
Santos, 1950
represents a junior subjective synonym of
N. phryne (
Perty, 1833
)
.

Diagnosis . Males of
Nephepeltia phryne
can be distinguished from all congeners by the conical spine about twice as long as wide on thoracic venter (
Fig. 8
; venter of thorax smoothly convex or with a tubercle about as long as wide or shorter in other species,
Figs. 6–7
). Spurs of inner row of male hind tibiae of about uniform placement and length (
Fig. 2
g) are shared with
N. aequisetis
,
N. berlai
, and
N. flavipennis
(
Figs. 2
a–b, e; closely set and peglike at medial 0.33 in
N. leonardina
and short and more closely set at basal 0.50–0.75 in
N. flavifrons
,
Figs. 2
c–d, f). Male vesica spermalis is similar to that of
N. leonardina
, by its latero-ectal distal lobes in the shape of curved spines and the absence of a medio-ectal distal process (
Figs. 11
e–f; latero-ectal lobes triangular, rectangular or oval in other species;
Figs. 11
a–d). Females of
N. phryne
can be recognized from those of
N. leonardina
by the radial planate consisting of three cells and the base of Fw discoidal planate with one cell (
Fig. 3
g; four or five and two respectively in
N. leonardina
,
Fig. 3
f), and from those of
N. aequisetis
by the presence of two cells between Fw subtriangle and hind margin of wing (
Fig. 3
g; one cell in
N. aequisetis
,
Fig. 3
a). The number of cells between Fw subtriangle and hind margin of wing is variable in
N. berlai
and
N. flavifrons
(one or two cells), and females of these species are indistinguishable morphologically from those of
N. phryne
.

Distribution .
Nephepeltia phryne
extends from Belize and Guatemala south to NE Argentina (
Donnelly et al. , 1998
), being the only species of the genus present in Trinidad (
Fig. 16
). Adults are commonly found perching on marginal vegetation of ponds along streams and rivers, temporary pools and ponds, ditches, marshes, and swamps (
Figs. 14
e–f). The last stadium larva was described based on a reared female from Venezuela (
De Marmels, 1990
).
